Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Cyborg Insect Networks for Exploration and Mapping (CINEMa)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Autonomous navigation in unknown and dynamic environments has been a major challenge for synthetic mobile robotic agents. On the other hand, insects can easily solve such complex navigational problems and demonstrate remarkably stable and optimized locomotion skills in almost any environment. This project aims to develop a mobile sensor network where insects are used as mobile biological-robotic (biobotic) nodes. Insects, in fact, build a "natural" sensor network through the use of their biological sensing organs and release of chemical, mechanical and optical cues to communicate the information to the rest of the group. In the scope of this project, a novel cyber-physical communication network will be established among the individual insect in addition to the aforementioned natural one. For this, insects will be equipped with synthetic electronic sensors to sense additional cues, neuromuscular stimulation systems to direct the control of the insect and microcontrollers with radios to establish an RF link between the insects. This novel network will enable operation of insect biobots in complicated and uncertain dynamic environments for applications such as environmental sensing and search-and-rescue operations after natural disasters.

The unique interdisciplinary nature of this project will help engineers to reach to younger generations and train them to be able to look at engineering problems from a cyberphysical systems point of view. Planned activities include development of lab modules and demos by undergraduate and graduate students to teach K-12 students and their teachers through our on-going collaborations with educational partners. These demos will also be instrumental during nation level efforts to promote graduate education to underrepresented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit outcomes: The proposal set out to create a technological platform for creating robotically controlled insects to enable short range search tasks such as locating disaster victims buried in rubble. These "biobots" would take advantage of the natural capabilities of insects for moving through the environment, but be directed by the attached electronics.  The insects in question were cockroaches and hawkmoths (a large moth with hovering capabilites). The UNC portion of this grant dealt with basic research on how hawkmoths control their flight speed and what the best speed for a biobot might be.  Experiments were conducted on moths flying in a wind tunnel with wire electrodes implanted in their flight muscles. These revealed that moths change speed by changing the activation rhythm of the wing-up and wing-down muscles. Furthermore, the moth results agreed well with classic aerodynamic models that predict a minimum flight cost at some intermediate speed. In the case of the moths, this minimum cost speed was 2 meters per second, so a searching biobot should spend most of its time at that speed, even if that means flying in a circle.  The UNC group also enabled experiments and work by the engineering team at NC State by providing moth pupae and testing the impact of implanted devices on flight performance. 

Broader impacts outcomes: The project contributed to the development of biobots as a reliable and useful mobile sensor platform, ultimate success in this area would provide a powerful new tool for disaster response and search in sitations where human exploration is difficult. The project also contributed to science outreach efforts at the NC Museum of Natural History BugFest! and the UNC Science Expo, where children were able to hold hawkmoths, hawkmoth pupae and even feed hovering hawkmoths by holding a flower for them. The downdraft of air that supports a hovering moth is easy to feel during feeding and these outreach efforts, targeted at broadly accessible and widely promoted events, inspire interest in biology, engineering and the overlap between the two.

The Intellectual merit and Broader impacts outcomes are both supported by the peer-reviewed papers in scientific journals and presentations of results at scientific conferences. Examples of these include:

Hedrick, T. L., Martínez-Blat, J., & Goodman, M. J. (2017). Flight motor modulation with speed in the hawkmoth Manduca sexta. Journal of Insect Physiology, 96, 115-121.
Hedrick, T. L., Ortega-Jimenez V. M., Raja, S. K., Khandelwal, P.  (2016). Hawkmoth Flight in Rotating Flows. Presentation at International Congress of Entomology, Orlando, FL.
Bozkurt, A., Lobaton, E., Sichitiu, M., Hedrick, T., Latif, T., Dirafzoon, A., ... & Xiong, H. (2014, June). Biobotic insect swarm based sensor networks for search and rescue. In SPIE Defense+ Security (pp. 90911L-90911L). International Society for Optics and Photonics.
